issue.title: Exit with code 1 when got errored tasks

repository.name: gulp
repository.description: A toolkit to automate & enhance your workflow

issue.body: Only after all tasks are done. Closes #88

body: @floatdrop Can't you just drop a process.exit(1) in https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/blob/master/bin/gulp.js#L137
@Contra that will exist on first failed task - what expected is exit after all tasks got a chance to run.
@floatdrop Ah. Is there any room to handle these errors gracefully and not exit with code 1?
@Contra this is what expect from us to do. This will signal automated build systems like travis or jenkins - that something wrong (i got about 20 build with success, before noticed that bug).
@floatdrop Yeah but I'm asking - is there a way for us to let the user gracefully handle the errors to prevent this behavior?

@Contra this isn't a user field of responsability, if this handler got error. This means, that all error handlers in tasks was either skipped or not binded to emitters (or try/catch was not placed) - so no, there's no way (imo).
@floatdrop I see what you're saying - they should just handle it inside the task thats failing. Seems good to me!
Orchestrator listens to the stream's `on('err'` so the stream believes it's handled.  Should Orchestrator throw if the orchestration ends in an error and there's no callback?

issue.title: Throw exception on end of failed orchestration with no callback

repository.name: orchestrator
repository.description: A module for sequencing and executing tasks and dependencies in maximum concurrency

issue.body: See https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/pull/88 and https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/pull/99 and https://github.com/gulpjs/gulp/issues/109

issue.title: Exit code 0 on failed require

repository.name: gulp
repository.description: A toolkit to automate & enhance your workflow

issue.body: #88 specifically references failed tasks for exit(1) behavior, but I've got a gulpfile with a failed `require` that [exits 0](https://travis-ci.org/popham/capnp-js/jobs/25633117).  Is this intended behavior?
